column5: Nice, I'll have to keep that in mind the next time I think about going abroad for fishing.
scarry....i thought credit river chinny's were big and ugly...these are on their own plateau

i remember when i was a kid my dad had a fishing magazine with an article about catching giant trout using dead squirrels as bait. i thought they were lake trout or something but i guess this must have been the same kind of fish in that article. this was 10 years ago or more...
Awesome. Correct me if I am wrong, but those look a lot like Brown Trout, or are they something completely different.
Man thats pretty amazing stuff,it sure would be cool to fish for them,how do i get to mongolia ????

....Taimen, been on my "must catch" fish wish list for some time, Solopaddlers as well if I remember right. Google it or check a few of the links I've searched quickly.  http://www.taimen.org/ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hucho_taimen

Yes has been on my wish list since about 1990 when I received this great book called Trout and Salmon of the World. Also Cherry Trout and Lennock.   The Cherry Trout     Couldnt Find a pic of a lennock but heres a link to the book. I highly recommend it . Beautiful pics of trout from all over the world will set your heart to dreaming  http://www.biblio.com/books/50398543.html
On my student budget I can't afford to dream lololol

Your a guide arent you. When I was a student I spent one summer working as a tech for the Alaskan DNR, doing spawning surveys in the remote wilderness didn't pay worth a crap but it was a trip of a lifetime.

They are a different genus (Hucho) than brown trout which are classified in the Salmo genus along with atlantic salmon.  Base on this, in don't think they are too closely related to browns despite their similar appearance.
